[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Integer Overflow] When converting from decimal=9 to target_decimal=255, can the repeated multiplication by 10 (246 times) cause value to overflow u256 max before the loop terminates, breaking oracle price feeds for assets with extreme decimal configurations? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Zero Value Bypass] Can an attacker pass value=0 with mismatched decimals to bypass all conversion logic and return 0, then use this in vault operations to claim assets are worthless when they have actual value? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Underflow to Zero] When converting large decimals to small decimals with small initial values (e.g., value=5, decimal=18, target_decimal=9), can repeated division by 10 round down to 0 prematurely, causing oracle to report zero price for valuable assets? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Rounding Direction Manipulation] Does the division by 10 always round down, allowing an attacker to systematically undervalue assets by choosing decimal conversions that maximize rounding losses across multiple price updates? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Precision Loss Accumulation] When vault performs multiple sequential decimal conversions (e.g., ETH price 18→9→6→9), can accumulated rounding errors compound to create significant value discrepancies enabling arbitrage or theft? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value_safe()] [Maximum Value Overflow] When value approaches u256::MAX and decimal < target_decimal, can the multiplication by 10 overflow silently in Move, wrapping around to small values and causing oracle to report drastically incorrect prices? [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_utils.move] [Function: to_target_decimal_value()] [Type Mismatch Exploit] The function uses u8 for decimals while to_target_decimal_value_safe() uses u64, can an attacker exploit different overflow boundaries (u8::MAX=255 vs u64::MAX) to cause inconsistent price conversions across vault operations?
